questions.text: All of the following are true regarding vitamin K, except-

options.label: A
options.text: Deficiency causes increase in clotting time

options.label: B
options.text: Common cause of deficiency is antibiotic used

questions.correct_answer: C. Required for activation of factor 8
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Deficiency causes an increase in clotting time: This is true. Without sufficient vitamin K, the gamma-carboxylation of the key clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X) is impaired, leading to the production of non-functional or poorly functional clotting proteins. This results in a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and an increased tendency to bleed. B. Common cause of deficiency is antibiotic use: This is also true. Vitamin K is synthesized by bacteria in the gut. Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt the normal gut flora, reducing the endogenous production of vitamin K. This, coupled with inadequate dietary intake, can lead to vitamin K deficiency, especially in individuals with poor nutrition or malabsorption issues. D. It is synthesized in the body: This is true. As mentioned above, bacteria in the intestinal tract, particularly the colon, synthesize vitamin K2 (menaquinones). While this endogenous production contributes to the body's vitamin K stores, it is often not sufficient to meet the total daily requirement, making dietary intake of vitamin K1 (phylloquinone) from leafy green vegetables and other sources essential. Why Vitamin K is NOT required for the activation of factor 8:
  • • Factor VIII is a crucial cofactor in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation. It is activated by thrombin and factor Xa. The activation of factor VIII does not involve vitamin K-dependent gamma-carboxylation. Factor VIII is a glycoprotein, and its function is dependent on its protein structure and interaction with other coagulation factors, particularly factor IXa.

questions.text: LDH flip in myocardial infarction is-
questions.correct_answer: A. LDH 1 is more than LDH-2
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. LDH-2 more than LDH-1: This represents the normal LDH isoenzyme pattern seen in healthy individuals and is not indicative of myocardial infarction. C. LDH-3 more than LDH-1: While LDH-3 is present in the serum, its elevation is more associated with lung injury or pulmonary embolism rather than myocardial infarction. D. LDH-1 more than LDH-3: While LDH-1 is elevated in MI, the key diagnostic feature of the LDH flip specifically involves the relationship between LDH-1 and LDH-2. LDH-1 being higher than LDH-3 alone is not the defining characteristic of the LDH flip in MI diagnosis.

questions.text: Most common product of fatty acid synthesis is-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Myristic acid: Myristic acid is a saturated fatty acid with 14 carbon atoms. While it can be synthesized in the body through the elongation of shorter fatty acids, it is not the primary end product of the core fatty acid synthesis pathway. B. Stearic acid: Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid with 18 carbon atoms. It is formed by the elongation of palmitic acid. Therefore, it is a subsequent product, not the most common initial product of fatty acid synthesis. C. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid with 20 carbon atoms and four double bonds. Its synthesis involves both elongation and desaturation of palmitic acid (or linoleic acid, an essential fatty acid). It is a more complex and further modified product, not the primary output of the fatty acid synthase complex.

questions.text: Nitric oxide works by-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. Cyclic AMP (cAMP): Cyclic AMP is another important second messenger, but it is primarily associated with signaling pathways involving G protein-coupled receptors and the enzyme adenylyl cyclase. While NO can indirectly influence cAMP levels in some contexts, its direct and primary mechanism of action does not involve cAMP. C. ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate): ATP is the main energy currency of the cell. While it plays a role in many cellular processes, it is not directly involved as a second messenger in the primary signaling pathway of nitric oxide. GTP is the direct precursor for cGMP synthesis by sGC. D. GTP (Guanosine Triphosphate): GTP is the substrate that soluble guanylate cyclase uses to synthesize cGMP upon activation by nitric oxide. While GTP is essential for NO signaling, it is the product of its action, cGMP, that acts as the second messenger to elicit downstream effects. Therefore, GTP itself is not the direct mediator of NO's effects in the same way that cGMP is.

questions.text: Tyrosinosis is probably caused due to defect in which enzyme-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Tyrosine transaminase: A deficiency in tyrosine transaminase leads to Tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome). This condition primarily affects the eyes, skin (palmoplantar keratosis), and can sometimes involve intellectual disability. It does not typically cause the severe liver and kidney issues seen in Tyrosinemia type I.
  • • C. Tyrosine aminotransferases: This is a general term for enzymes that catalyze the transamination of tyrosine. While tyrosine transaminase (mentioned above) falls under this category, the specific defect in classic Tyrosinemia type I is with fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase, which acts much later in the tyrosine degradation pathway.
  • • D. 4 hydroxy PPD deficiency: 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (4-HPPD) is the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate to homogentisate in the tyrosine degradation pathway. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to Tyrosinemia type III, a very rare condition characterized primarily by neurological problems, including intellectual disability and ataxia. It does not typically cause the severe liver disease associated with Tyrosinemia type I.

questions.text: Galactosemia is most commonly caused due to defect in-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Galactokinase: A defect in galactokinase leads to Galactosemia type II. This is a milder form of galactosemia, primarily characterized by the development of cataracts. While there is an accumulation of galactose, galactose-1-phosphate levels are not as significantly elevated as in classic galactosemia, and the severe systemic complications seen in type I are usually absent. B. Aldolase B: Aldolase B is an enzyme involved in fructose metabolism, specifically in the breakdown of fructose-1-phosphate. A deficiency in aldolase B causes hereditary fructose intolerance, a metabolic disorder distinct from galactosemia with different clinical manifestations. D. Phosphoglucomutase: Phosphoglucomutase catalyzes the interconversion of glucose-1-phosphate and glucose-6-phosphate, a step in both glycogen metabolism and the Leloir pathway (after galactose has been converted to glucose-1-phosphate). While a defect in phosphoglucomutase (PGM1) can cause glycogen storage disease type XIV, it is not the primary cause of classic galactosemia. Defects in PGM1 are much rarer than GALT deficiency as a cause of galactose metabolism disorders.

questions.text: True about DNA polymerase 1 is?

options.label: A
options.text: It extends okazaki fragments on RNA primer

options.label: C
options.text: It does proof reading and repair

options.label: D
options.text: Main enzyme in bacteria for bacterial replication

questions.correct_answer: B. It has proof reading activity
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. It extends Okazaki fragments on the RNA primer: While DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme that extends Okazaki fragments during bacterial DNA replication, DNA polymerase I plays a crucial role after the extension. It uses its 5' to 3' exonuclease activity to remove the RNA primers that initiated each Okazaki fragment and then uses its 5' to 3' polymerase activity to fill the resulting gaps with DNA.
  • • C. It does proofreading and repair: This statement is also true. As mentioned above, the 3' to 5' exonuclease activity provides proofreading. Additionally, DNA polymerase I is significantly involved in various DNA repair pathways, utilizing both its polymerase and exonuclease activities to remove damaged DNA and synthesize new, correct sequences. However, option B specifically highlights the proofreading activity, which is a key and well-established characteristic of DNA polymerase I. Option B is more concise and directly addresses a fundamental property.
  • • D. Main enzyme in bacteria for bacterial replication: The main enzyme responsible for the bulk of DNA synthesis during bacterial replication is DNA polymerase III. DNA polymerase I plays more of a supporting role in primer removal and gap filling, as well as DNA repair. DNA polymerase III has a much higher processivity (ability to synthesize long stretches of DNA without dissociating) and a faster polymerization rate, making it the primary replicative enzyme.

questions.text: Negative charge carrying amino acid are-
questions.correct_answer: B. Glutamic acid and aspartic acid
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Glutamic acid and aspartic acid are classified as acidic amino acids. Their side chains (R-groups) contain a carboxyl group (-COOH) that can deprotonate at physiological pH (around 7.4), releasing a proton (H+ ) and becoming negatively charged (−COO− ). This makes them key players in forming salt bridges and contributing to the overall negative charge of proteins, which is crucial for protein structure, function, and interaction with other molecules. The pKa values for the side chain carboxyl groups of aspartic acid and glutamic acid are approximately 3.9 and 4.3, respectively. Since these values are well below physiological pH, these groups will largely be deprotonated and thus negatively charged in most biological environments.
  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • A) Serine and threonine: Serine and threonine are uncharged polar amino acids. Their side chains contain a hydroxyl group (-OH), which is polar but does not typically ionize to carry a formal charge at physiological pH.
  • • C) Histidine and lysine: Histidine and lysine are basic amino acids. Their side chains contain nitrogenous groups (an imidazole ring for histidine and an amino group for lysine) that can accept a proton (H+ ) at physiological pH, thereby becoming positively charged. Histidine has a pKa near physiological pH (around 6.0), meaning it can be uncharged or positively charged depending on the exact pH, while lysine (pKa around 10.5) is almost always positively charged at physiological pH.
  • • D) Valine and isoleucine: Valine and isoleucine are nonpolar, aliphatic amino acids. Their side chains consist entirely of hydrocarbon chains, which are hydrophobic and do not possess any ionizable groups that would carry a charge at physiological pH.

questions.text: Allosteric inhibitor acts on which site to inhibit enzyme action?

options.label: C
options.text: Does not act on any site

options.label: D
options.text: Acts on both sites and block

questions.correct_answer: A. Site other than enzymatic site

questions.text: Ketone bodies cannot be utilized by-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • D) RBCs: Red blood cells (erythrocytes) lack mitochondria. The complete oxidation of ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) to produce energy requires a functional electron transport chain and Krebs cycle, both of which are localized within the mitochondria. Since RBCs are anucleated and lack these organelles, they cannot metabolize ketone bodies for energy. Their primary energy source is glucose, which they metabolize through anaerobic glycolysis.
  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • A) Heart: The heart is a highly aerobic organ with a high demand for energy. In conditions of fasting, prolonged exercise, or starvation, the heart can readily utilize ketone bodies as a significant fuel source, in addition to fatty acids and glucose. B) Brain: While glucose is the primary fuel for the brain under normal conditions, during prolonged fasting, starvation, or in individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, the brain adapts to utilize ketone bodies (specifically acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) as a crucial alternative energy source. This adaptation is vital for survival when glucose supply is limited. C) Skeletal muscles: Skeletal muscles are also capable of utilizing ketone bodies for energy, especially during prolonged exercise or starvation. They have the necessary enzymes (like β-ketoacyl-CoA transferase or succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase) and mitochondria to oxidize ketone bodies to acetyl-CoA, which then enters the Krebs cycle.

questions.text: Methylation of cytosine is associated with:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A) Decreased expression of gene: Methylation of cytosine residues, particularly when it occurs in CpG islands located in gene promoter regions, is a well-established epigenetic mechanism that typically leads to gene silencing or decreased gene expression. The added methyl group (CH3) to the cytosine base can physically block the binding of transcription factors, or it can recruit proteins that condense chromatin structure, making the DNA less accessible to the transcriptional machinery. This effectively "turns off" or dampens the activity of the associated gene.
  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • B) Increased expression of gene: While some epigenetic modifications (like certain histone modifications) can lead to increased gene expression, cytosine methylation in promoter regions is overwhelmingly associated with a decrease in gene expression. C) Mutation: Methylation is an epigenetic modification, meaning it alters gene expression without changing the underlying DNA sequence. A mutation, on the other hand, is a change in the DNA sequence itself. While methylated cytosine can spontaneously deaminate to thymine (leading to a C to T mutation), methylation itself is not a mutation. D) No effect: Cytosine methylation is a critical regulatory mechanism in gene expression and plays a significant role in various biological processes, including development, differentiation, and disease. Therefore, it definitely has an effect on gene expression.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to lack of?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • C) Peroxisomes: Zellweger syndrome (also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome) is a rare, inherited disorder that is part of a group of conditions called peroxisome biogenesis disorders (PBDs). It is characterized by the absence or severe reduction of functional peroxisomes in cells. Peroxisomes are crucial organelles involved in a variety of metabolic processes, including the β-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs), the synthesis of plasmalogens (essential membrane lipids), and the detoxification of harmful substances. The lack of functional peroxisomes leads to the accumulation of toxic metabolites, causing severe neurological dysfunction, liver failure, and other systemic issues.
  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • A) Lysosomes: Lysosomes are organelles responsible for cellular waste disposal and recycling, breaking down various macromolecules. Disorders related to lysosomal dysfunction are known as lysosomal storage diseases (e.g., Tay-Sachs disease, Gaucher disease), which have different clinical manifestations than Zellweger syndrome. B) Mitochondria: Mitochondria are the primary sites of ATP production through cellular respiration. Disorders involving mitochondrial dysfunction (e.g., mitochondrial encephalomyopathies) affect energy production and have a different set of symptoms compared to Zellweger syndrome. D) Nucleus: The nucleus contains the cell's genetic material (DNA) and controls cell growth and reproduction. While genetic mutations cause Zellweger syndrome, the syndrome itself is not due to a "lack of nucleus." All eukaryotic cells have a nucleus (except mature red blood cells), and its absence would be incompatible with life. The problem in Zellweger syndrome lies in the functionality of peroxisomes, not the absence of the nucleus.

questions.text: Urea, creatinine and nitric oxide are formed by which amino acid?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • D) Arginine: Arginine is a versatile amino acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of several important biological molecules:
  • • Urea: Arginine is a key intermediate in the urea cycle, which is the primary pathway for the removal of toxic ammonia from the body. In the final step of the urea cycle, arginase converts arginine into urea and ornithine. Creatinine: Arginine, along with glycine and methionine, is a precursor to creatine. Creatine is then phosphorylated to phosphocreatine, an important energy reserve in muscles. Creatinine is a breakdown product of creatine and phosphocreatine, which is excreted in urine. Nitric Oxide (NO): Arginine is the sole substrate for nitric oxide synthase (NOS) enzymes, which produce nitric oxide. Nitric oxide is a crucial signaling molecule involved in various physiological processes, including vasodilation, neurotransmission, and immune responses. Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • A) Histidine: Histidine is a precursor for histamine, a mediator of allergic reactions and a neurotransmitter. It is not directly involved in the synthesis of urea, creatinine, or nitric oxide. B) Glycine: Glycine is a component of creatine (along with arginine and methionine) and is involved in the synthesis of heme, purines, and glutathione. However, it is arginine that serves as the direct precursor for urea and nitric oxide, and is a key precursor (along with methionine) for the pathway that ultimately leads to creatinine. C) Cysteine: Cysteine contains sulfur and is involved in the synthesis of glutathione, coenzyme A, and taurine. It is also important for disulfide bond formation in proteins. It is not a direct precursor for urea, creatinine, or nitric oxide.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the source of cytosolic NADPH
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B) ATP citrate lyase: ATP citrate lyase is an enzyme that catalyzes the cleavage of citrate into oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA. This reaction is crucial for providing cytosolic acetyl-CoA for fatty acid and cholesterol synthesis. While it links carbohydrate metabolism to lipid synthesis, it does not directly produce NADPH. It is an ATP-dependent enzyme, meaning it consumes ATP, rather than producing reducing equivalents like NADPH.
  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • A) Isocitrate dehydrogenase: While the primary isocitrate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle is mitochondrial and produces NADH, there is a cytosolic isoform of NADP-dependent isocitrate dehydrogenase. This cytosolic enzyme catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate, producing NADPH in the process. This is a significant source of cytosolic NADPH, particularly in tissues involved in reductive biosynthesis. C) Malic enzyme: The malic enzyme (specifically the NADP-dependent cytosolic form) catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate, simultaneously producing NADPH. This reaction is a major source of cytosolic NADPH, especially in tissues like adipose tissue and liver, where it provides reducing power for fatty acid synthesis. D) G6PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase): G6PD is the rate-limiting enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP). The first step of the PPP, catalyzed by G6PD, is the oxidation of glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconolactone, and in this reaction, NADP + is reduced to NADPH. The pentose phosphate pathway is the primary source of cytosolic NADPH in most cells, particularly for reductive biosynthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione against oxidative stress.

questions.text: All are true regarding mitochondrial DNA except

options.label: D
options.text: All respiratory proteins are synthesised in mitochondria

questions.correct_answer: D. All respiratory proteins are synthesised in mitochondria
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A) Double stranded: Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is indeed a double-stranded, circular molecule in most eukaryotes, including humans. This is similar to bacterial DNA, supporting the endosymbiotic theory of mitochondrial origin. B) Inherited from maternal side: In humans and most other mammals, mitochondrial DNA is almost exclusively inherited from the mother. During fertilization, the egg contributes the cytoplasm, which contains mitochondria, while the sperm primarily contributes its nucleus. Therefore, offspring inherit their mtDNA solely from their mother. C) High mutation rate: Mitochondrial DNA has a significantly higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA. This is attributed to several factors, including the lack of protective histones, proximity to reactive oxygen species generated during oxidative phosphorylation, and less efficient DNA repair mechanisms within the mitochondria. Explanation for Correct Answer (False statement about mitochondrial DNA):
  • • D) All respiratory proteins are synthesised in mitochondria: This statement is false. While mitochondria have their own genetic material and ribosomes to synthesize some of their proteins, the vast majority of mitochondrial proteins, including many essential components of the electron transport chain and ATP synthase (which are crucial for respiration), are encoded by nuclear DNA, synthesized in the cytosol, and then imported into the mitochondria. Only a small subset of proteins (typically 13 in humans) involved in oxidative phosphorylation are encoded by mtDNA and synthesized within the mitochondria. Therefore, not all respiratory proteins are synthesized in mitochondria.

questions.text: Hyperammonemia inhibits TCA cycle by depleting?
Menke’s disease is associated with which enzyme deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A) Lysyl oxidase: Menkes disease (also known as Menkes kinky hair syndrome) is a rare, X-linked recessive genetic disorder characterized by a defect in copper transport. It is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, which encodes a copper-transporting P-type ATPase. This protein is essential for the absorption of copper from the diet and its distribution to various tissues, including the brain, hair, and connective tissue.
  • • A key consequence of copper deficiency in Menkes disease is the impaired activity of lysyl oxidase. Lysyl oxidase is a copper-dependent enzyme that catalyzes the oxidative deamination of lysine and hydroxylysine residues in collagen and elastin. This cross-linking process is crucial for the structural integrity and strength of connective tissues, blood vessels, and hair. In Menkes disease, the reduced activity of lysyl oxidase due to copper deficiency leads to weak, brittle hair (kinky hair), fragile arteries prone to rupture, connective tissue laxity, and neurological degeneration.
  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • B) Methionine synthase: Methionine synthase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of methionine and homocysteine, requiring vitamin B 12 as a cofactor. Deficiencies in this enzyme are associated with homocystinuria, not Menkes disease.
  • • C) Glutamyl amino peptidase: This enzyme, also known as aminopeptidase N, is involved in peptide degradation and is not directly associated with Menkes disease.
  • • D) Lysyl hydroxylase: Lysyl hydroxylase is another enzyme involved in collagen synthesis. It catalyzes the hydroxylation of lysine residues, which is important for collagen cross-linking and stability. While it is a copper-dependent enzyme and its activity could theoretically be affected by severe copper deficiency, the primary and most directly impacted enzyme in Menkes disease leading to the characteristic connective tissue problems is lysyl oxidase due to its direct role in the crucial cross-linking step. Lysyl hydroxylase also requires vitamin C (ascorbate) as a cofactor, and its deficiency leads to scurvy, which has different clinical features. Lysyl oxidase is the most fitting answer in the context of Menkes disease's direct impact on copper-dependent enzymes involved in connective tissue integrity.

questions.text: LCAT deficiency increases which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A) HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein): LCAT (Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase) is an enzyme that plays a critical role in cholesterol metabolism, particularly in the maturation of HDL. LCAT catalyzes the esterification of cholesterol in HDL particles, converting free cholesterol into cholesterol esters. Cholesterol esters are more hydrophobic than free cholesterol and can move into the core of the HDL particle, allowing the HDL to take up more free cholesterol from peripheral tissues. This process is essential for the "reverse cholesterol transport" pathway, where excess cholesterol is transported back to the liver for excretion.
  • • In LCAT deficiency, the esterification of cholesterol is impaired. This leads to an accumulation of unesterified cholesterol in the plasma, primarily on the surface of lipoproteins, especially HDL. The nascent HDL particles, which are discoidal and rich in free cholesterol, cannot be efficiently converted into mature, spherical HDL particles because LCAT is not working. This leads to the presence of abnormal, immature HDL particles and, paradoxically, an increase in the overall amount of HDL (though it's dysfunctional) as the body attempts to compensate and due to the accumulation of unesterified cholesterol on HDL. While the total HDL level might appear increased, it's often dysfunctional HDL. The question asks what increases, and the accumulation of these unesterified cholesterol-rich particles within the HDL fraction leads to an increased measurement of HDL.
  • • Explanation for Incorrect Answers:
  • • B) LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein): LDL primarily transports cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues. LCAT deficiency doesn't directly cause an increase in LDL levels; instead, it affects the composition and metabolism of HDL, which can indirectly impact the overall lipoprotein profile but doesn't primarily lead to an increase in LDL. C) VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein): VLDL transports triglycerides from the liver to peripheral tissues. While there might be secondary effects on VLDL metabolism in LCAT deficiency, it is not the primary lipoprotein that directly increases due to the lack of LCAT activity. D) Chylomicron: Chylomicrons are responsible for transporting dietary triglycerides from the intestines. LCAT is not directly involved in chylomicron metabolism to the extent that its deficiency would cause a direct increase in chylomicrons.

questions.text: A 25 yr old alcoholic presented with edema, hypertension, ocular disturbances and altered mental status. Diagnosis of wet beri beri with high output cardiac failure wasmade. This is due to deficiency of?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A) Vit B3 (Niacin): Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by "the 4 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death. While neurological symptoms can occur, the specific constellation of high-output cardiac failure and ocular disturbances as the primary presentation points away from niacin deficiency. B) Vit B6 (Pyridoxine): Pyridoxine deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms (e.g., neuropathy, seizures), skin changes, and anemia. It is not directly associated with high-output cardiac failure or the characteristic edema seen in wet beriberi. C) Vit B9 (Folic Acid): Folic acid deficiency primarily causes megaloblastic anemia and can lead to neurological symptoms (e.g., peripheral neuropathy) and some gastrointestinal issues. It does not cause the cardiovascular or ocular symptoms typical of beriberi.

questions.text: Increased glutamine in blood, urine and CSF is due to deficiency of ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B) Arginase: Arginase is the final enzyme in the urea cycle, converting arginine to urea and ornithine. A deficiency in arginase leads to hyperargininemia (high arginine levels) and hyperammonemia, but the primary accumulation would be arginine, not glutamine, as the upstream steps are still functional and can proceed to arginine synthesis. While glutamine might be elevated due to hyperammonemia, it's not the direct or primary consequence of arginase deficiency compared to CPS I. C) OTC (Ornithine Transcarbamylase): OTC deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder. OTC catalyzes the second step of the urea cycle, combining carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. Like CPS I deficiency, OTC deficiency also leads to severe hyperammonemia because ammonia cannot be efficiently converted to urea. This hyperammonemia also leads to increased glutamine synthesis and elevated glutamine levels. However, CPS I deficiency is often associated with the most severe hyperammonemia and, consequently, the most pronounced glutamine accumulation as the block is at the very first step of ammonia incorporation into the urea cycle. Given the options, CPS I directly impacts the initial ammonia fixation. D) Arginosuccinate lyase: Arginosuccinate lyase (ASL) is an enzyme in the urea cycle that converts argininosuccinate to arginine and fumarate. A deficiency in ASL leads to the accumulation of argininosuccinate in the blood and urine, along with hyperammonemia. While hyperammonemia would indirectly lead to increased glutamine, the primary accumulating metabolite associated with ASL deficiency is argininosuccinate, not glutamine as a direct product of the block itself.

questions.text: Type I hyperlipoproteinemia is characterised by
The linking compound between kreb’s cycle and urea cycle is?
In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency which of the following is increased after a fatty meal?
Replacing alamine by which amino acid, will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280 mm wavelength?
No is synthesized from:
Apolipoprotein B48?
Vit. B12 is found maximum in:
Enzyme activated by decrease in insulin: glucogon ratio:
Image of casal’s necklace. Which vitamin deficiency?

A 45 yrs old presents with paresthesia. Hb = 6.8 g/dL Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and neutrophils with hypersegmented nuclei. Endoscopy reveals atropic gastritis. Which of the following deficiency is more likely?
In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following lipid would be deficient?
A child presented with night blindness, Bitot’s spot. Dermatological finding is as given below. What is the diagnosis
A person presents with Tendon Xanthoma. Serum cholesterol and LDL elevated. Values are respectively 398 and 220 mg/dl. Treatment with statin was initiated. Most probable disorder is
A person has Cystathionine beta synthases deficiency. Supplementation of which of the amino acid is needed.
5 year old male patient presents with anaemia, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly. Macrophages showed crumbled tissue paper appearance. The deficient enzyme is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Option (C. α-Galactosidase) Explanation: A deficiency in α-Galactosidase (alpha-galactosidase A) causes Fabry disease. This X-linked lysosomal storage disorder primarily affects various organs, leading to symptoms like neuropathic pain, angiokeratomas (skin lesions), kidney disease, and cardiac problems. It does not typically present with the "crumbled tissue paper" macrophages or significant hepatosplenomegaly as a hallmark.
  • • Option (D. β-Galactosidase) Explanation: A deficiency in β-Galactosidase can lead to several lysosomal storage disorders, most notably GM1 Gangliosidosis and Morquio Syndrome Type B. While GM1 Gangliosidosis can involve hepatosplenomegaly and neurological issues, it does not produce the specific "crumbled tissue paper" Gaucher cells. The lysosomal inclusions in GM1 Gangliosidosis are often described differently (e.g., "foamy" cells).
  • • Glucocerebrosidase
  • • The clinical presentation of a 5-year-old male with anemia, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and most importantly, macrophages with a "crumpled tissue paper appearance" on peripheral smear, is highly characteristic of Gaucher disease.
  • • Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused by a genetic deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucocerebrosidase or acid beta-glucosidase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down the fatty substance glucocerebroside (also called glucosylceramide) within lysosomes. When the enzyme is deficient, glucocerebroside accumulates in the lysosomes, particularly within macrophages (a type of white blood cell). These lipid-laden macrophages, known as "Gaucher cells," swell and take on their distinctive "crumpled tissue paper" or "wrinkled tissue paper" appearance under a microscope. The accumulation of these Gaucher cells in various organs, especially the spleen, liver, and bone marrow, leads to the characteristic symptoms: hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), anemia (due to bone marrow infiltration), and bone pain (due to bone marrow involvement and sometimes avascular necrosis).
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. Hexosaminidase A: Deficiency of Hexosaminidase A causes Tay-Sachs disease, another lysosomal storage disorder. Tay-Sachs is primarily a severe neurodegenerative disorder of infancy, characterized by progressive neurological deterioration, exaggerated startle reflex, and a "cherry-red spot" on the retina. It does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, or the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance of macrophages; instead, it is characterized by the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides in neurons.
  • • C. α-Galactosidase: Deficiency of α-Galactosidase A causes Fabry disease, an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder. Fabry disease affects various organs and typically presents with painful acroparesthesias (burning pain in hands and feet), angiokeratomas (small, dark red spots on the skin), corneal opacities, and progressive kidney and heart disease. It does not lead to the "crumpled tissue paper" macrophages or the specific pattern of anemia, bone pain, and hepatosplenomegaly seen in Gaucher disease.
  • • D. β-Galactosidase: Deficiency of β-Galactosidase can cause GM1 gangliosidosis or Morquio Syndrome B. GM1 gangliosidosis is a severe neurodegenerative lysosomal storage disorder characterized by coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, and a "cherry-red spot" in some cases. While hepatosplenomegaly can occur, the characteristic macrophage appearance and primary symptoms differ from Gaucher disease.

questions.text: Glucose Transporter in adipose cell
Type of defect seen in HNPCC
History of passing black coloured urine and black discoloration of cartilages. What is the enzyme deficiency
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, also commonly referred to as HGA oxidase (or homogentisic acid oxidase). This enzyme plays a crucial role in the metabolic pathway that breaks down the amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine. Specifically, it is responsible for converting homogentisic acid (HGA) into maleylacetoacetic acid.
  • • When HGA oxidase is deficient or non-functional, homogentisic acid cannot be properly metabolized and accumulates in the body. This excess HGA is then excreted in the urine, which turns dark brown or black upon exposure to air due to the oxidation of HGA. Over time, HGA also deposits in various connective tissues throughout the body, including cartilage, tendons, and skin. This deposition of oxidized HGA polymer leads to a bluish-black discoloration of these tissues, a condition known as ochronosis. Ochronosis is particularly noticeable in the ear cartilage, sclera of the eyes, and large joints. The accumulation of HGA in cartilage also leads to degenerative arthritis, especially in the spine and large joints, which can be severely debilitating.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • A) Homogentisic acid dehydrogenase: While "dehydrogenase" is a type of enzyme, the specific enzyme deficient in Alkaptonuria is homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase (HGA oxidase), not a dehydrogenase. This option uses a similar-sounding name but refers to a different enzymatic function.
  • • B) 2,4 D phenyl acetic acid Hydrolase: This enzyme is not involved in the metabolic pathway of tyrosine and phenylalanine, nor is its deficiency associated with alkaptonuria or the described symptoms.
  • • C) HGA Oxidase: This is a synonym for homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, and therefore is effectively the correct answer. The question provided "HGA" as option D, which is the substrate that accumulates due to the deficiency of HGA Oxidase. Given that HGA Oxidase is the direct enzyme deficiency, this option would be the most precise if available in a full form. However, since the question provided "HGA" as a standalone option in context of enzyme deficiency, it's possible it implicitly refers to "HGA Oxidase." But, looking at the pattern of multiple-choice questions in this context, "HGA" on its own would refer to the acid that accumulates, not the enzyme. The most accurate enzyme name is homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase or HGA oxidase. If the options are strict, and 'D' is meant to be the exact name of the enzyme, then the option should have been "HGA Oxidase" or "Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase". Since the question states "Correct Answer (D)", it implies that "HGA" itself was somehow taken to refer to the enzyme, perhaps as a shorthand. However, in a biochemical sense, HGA is the substrate. The actual enzyme is HGA oxidase. Given the provided answer, it implies a slight imprecision in option (D) as presented in the question, but the underlying concept is that the oxidase that acts on HGA is deficient.

questions.text: Corneal transparency is due to
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Corneal transparency is a marvel of biological engineering, maintained by a highly precise arrangement of collagen fibrils in the corneal stroma. The stroma, which makes up the bulk of the cornea, consists of uniformly sized and regularly spaced collagen fibrils. This precise arrangement is crucial because any disruption in the uniformity or spacing of these fibrils would lead to light scattering and corneal opacity.
  • • Keratan sulfate (KS) is the predominant glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in the corneal stroma, present as part of proteoglycans (KSPGs) like lumican, keratocan, and mimecan. These KSPGs play a critical role in maintaining the precise interfibrillar spacing and uniform diameter of the collagen fibrils. They bind to specific sites on the collagen fibrils, preventing their aggregation and ensuring an organized lattice structure. The specific sulfation patterns of keratan sulfate chains are particularly important for these interactions. Evidence from conditions like macular corneal dystrophy, where there is a defect in keratan sulfate sulfation, demonstrates that the absence or alteration of functional keratan sulfate leads to corneal opacification, highlighting its essential role in maintaining transparency.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • B) Dermatan sulfate: While dermatan sulfate (DS) proteoglycans (like decorin) are also present in the cornea, they are less abundant than keratan sulfate proteoglycans in the stromal layer and their primary role is more in regulating collagen fibrillogenesis and contributing to the overall extracellular matrix structure, rather than being the primary determinant of the precise interfibrillar spacing crucial for transparency in the same way keratan sulfate is.
  • • C) Heparan sulfate: Heparan sulfate (HS) proteoglycans are found in the cornea, particularly in the epithelial and endothelial layers, where they play roles in cell-surface interactions, cell adhesion, and signaling. While essential for overall corneal health and function, they are not the main GAG responsible for maintaining the unique collagen organization and light transparency of the corneal stroma.
  • • D) Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate (CS) is present in the cornea, often in a hybrid form with dermatan sulfate (CS/DS). Like dermatan sulfate, it contributes to the overall extracellular matrix and collagen organization, and has roles in cell signaling and maintaining the stem cell niche. However, it is not the primary GAG that dictates the precise interfibrillar spacing of collagen critical for transparency to the same extent as keratan sulfate.

questions.text: Enzyme activity to asses riboflavin (B2) levels?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is a precursor to two important coenzymes: flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). FAD is a crucial coenzyme for many enzymatic reactions, including that of glutathione reductase.
  • • Glutathione reductase is an enzyme found abundantly in red blood cells (erythrocytes). Its primary function is to reduce oxidized glutathione (GSSG) back to its reduced form (GSH), which is essential for maintaining the antioxidant defenses of the cell. This reaction directly requires FAD as a cofactor.
  • • To assess riboflavin status, a common and reliable method is to measure the activity of erythrocyte glutathione reductase before and after the addition of exogenous FAD.
  • • In riboflavin-deficient individuals, the baseline activity of glutathione reductase will be lower because there isn't enough FAD available to saturate the enzyme. When FAD is added to the assay mixture (in vitro), the enzyme's activity will significantly increase if the deficiency is due to insufficient FAD. The "activity coefficient" (or "stimulation coefficient") is calculated as the ratio of stimulated activity (with added FAD) to unstimulated activity (without added FAD). A higher activity coefficient indicates a greater degree of riboflavin deficiency. Therefore, measuring erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity and its stimulation by FAD is a highly specific and sensitive functional assay for assessing riboflavin nutritional status.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • A) Erythrocyte transketolase activity: This enzyme's activity is used to assess thiamine (Vitamin B1) status. Transketolase requires thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), the active form of thiamine, as a cofactor. Similar to the glutathione reductase assay, transketolase activity is measured before and after the addition of TPP to determine thiamine deficiency.
  • • C) Erythrocyte transaminase activity: Transaminases (like aspartate transaminase or alanine transaminase) primarily require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of Vitamin B6, as a coenzyme. Therefore, measuring erythrocyte transaminase activity is used to assess Vitamin B6 status.
  • • D) Glucose 6 phosphatase: Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme primarily found in the liver and kidneys, crucial for glucose homeostasis (releasing glucose from the liver into the bloodstream). Its activity is not directly used to assess riboflavin levels. Defects in this enzyme are associated with Von Gierke's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), but not with vitamin B2 deficiency.

questions.text: A young woman took over the counter medicines for weight loss presented with fat malabsorbtion and bleeding tendencies and easy bruising. Which of the following is probable vitamin deficiency ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The patient's symptoms of fat malabsorption, bleeding tendencies, and easy bruising strongly point towards a deficiency of a fat-soluble vitamin. Among the options provided, Vitamin K is the most probable.
  • • Here's why:
  • • Fat Malabsorption: The patient took "over-the-counter medicines for weight loss." Many such medications, particularly those containing orlistat, work by inhibiting pancreatic lipase, thereby reducing the absorption of dietary fats. Since Vitamins A, D, E, and K are fat-soluble, anything that impairs fat absorption will also impair the absorption of these vitamins.
  • • Bleeding Tendencies and Easy Bruising: This is the hallmark symptom of Vitamin K deficiency. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of several clotting factors (Factor II, VII, IX, X) in the liver. These factors require Vitamin K-dependent carboxylation to become biologically active. Without sufficient Vitamin K, these clotting factors are non-functional, leading to impaired blood coagulation, manifested as prolonged bleeding (e.g., from minor cuts), easy bruising, and in severe cases, internal hemorrhages.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • A) Vitamin C: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a water-soluble vitamin. While severe Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) can lead to bleeding gums, perifollicular hemorrhages, and poor wound healing due to impaired collagen synthesis, it is not directly linked to fat malabsorption. Furthermore, "easy bruising" is a general symptom that could fit, but the combination with fat malabsorption makes Vitamin K a much stronger candidate.
  • • C) Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Riboflavin is a water-soluble vitamin. Deficiency of riboflavin can cause symptoms like angular stomatitis, cheilosis, glossitis, and dermatitis, but it does not directly lead to fat malabsorption or bleeding tendencies.
  • • D) Biotin (Vitamin B7): Biotin is also a water-soluble vitamin. Biotin deficiency is rare but can cause symptoms like dermatitis, hair loss (alopecia), and neurological symptoms. It is not associated with fat malabsorption or bleeding disorders.

questions.text: A patient on anti tuberculosis drugs for last 3 months present with bilateral tingling sensations and mood changes. Probable vitamin deficiency
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The key information in this scenario is that the patient is on "anti-tuberculosis drugs" and presents with "bilateral tingling sensations and mood changes." This clinical picture is highly suggestive of peripheral neuropathy and neurological symptoms, which are well-known side effects of certain anti-tuberculosis medications, particularly Isoniazid (INH).
  • • Isoniazid is a potent drug used in the treatment of tuberculosis. Its mechanism of action can lead to a functional deficiency of Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine). Isoniazid interferes with pyridoxine metabolism in several ways:
  • • It can form an inactive hydrazone complex with pyridoxal phosphate (the active form of Vitamin B6), increasing its excretion in urine. It can inhibit pyridoxine phosphokinase, an enzyme needed to convert pyridoxine into its active form. This induced Vitamin B6 deficiency leads to peripheral neuropathy (tingling sensations, numbness, pain, particularly in the hands and feet) because pyridoxal phosphate is essential for the synthesis of neurotransmitters (like GABA and serotonin) and for the proper functioning of the nervous system. Mood changes (irritability, depression, confusion) are also recognized neurological symptoms of Vitamin B6 deficiency. For this reason, patients on isoniazid therapy are often prescribed pyridoxine supplementation to prevent or mitigate these side effects.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • B) Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency (cobalamin deficiency) can also cause neurological symptoms, including peripheral neuropathy, numbness, tingling, and cognitive changes (memory problems, depression). However, it is not a direct or common side effect of standard anti-tuberculosis drug regimens in the same way that isoniazid causes B6 deficiency. While a general nutritional deficiency could theoretically encompass B12, the specific drug context strongly points to B6.
  • • C) Folate: Folate (Vitamin B9) deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia and some neurological or psychiatric symptoms like depression, irritability, and cognitive impairment. However, it is not primarily known for causing peripheral neuropathy as a direct consequence of anti-tuberculosis drugs, and it's less commonly associated with the specific "tingling sensations" (paresthesias) seen in B6 deficiency.
  • • D) Not provided in the question's options, but if it were another vitamin like Thiamine (B1): Thiamine deficiency (beriberi) can cause peripheral neuropathy ("dry beriberi") and neurological symptoms, but it is not specifically induced by anti-tuberculosis drugs.

questions.text: A child with rice water stools presented to emergency in a unstable state. A toxin causing this condition acts via which of the following lipid receptor ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B) Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is a type of sphingolipid, a component of cell membranes, but it is not the specific lipid receptor for cholera toxin. While general membrane lipids are involved in the overall structure and trafficking, GM1 ganglioside is the specific, high-affinity binding target.
  • • C) GM2 ganglioside: GM2 ganglioside is another type of ganglioside, but it is not the primary receptor for cholera toxin. While some toxins or pathogens might interact with other gangliosides, the specific and critical receptor for cholera toxin is GM1. Defects in GM2 metabolism are associated with Tay-Sachs disease.
  • • D) ?: This option is incomplete, but based on the specificity of cholera toxin, any other generic or unrelated lipid receptor would be incorrect.

questions.text: A young man presented with physical activity intolerance,painful muscle cramps, weakness, and fatigue. ( High CK levels and myoglobinuria , biopsy revealed high glycogen content on PAS staining) A diagnosis of Mc-Ardles disease was made. Which of the following enzyme is deficient
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation described – physical activity intolerance, painful muscle cramps, weakness, fatigue, high CK levels, myoglobinuria, and high glycogen content on PAS staining in muscle biopsy – is the classic constellation of symptoms and findings for McArdle's disease.
  • • McArdle's disease, also known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type V (GSD V), is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme muscle glycogen phosphorylase, also known as myophosphorylase.
  • • Here's why this enzyme deficiency leads to the observed symptoms:
  • • Myophosphorylase is specifically responsible for initiating the breakdown of glycogen (stored glucose) in skeletal muscles. It cleaves glucose-1-phosphate from the glycogen polymer, which can then enter glycolysis to produce ATP for muscle contraction. In McArdle's disease, due to the deficiency of myophosphorylase, muscles cannot effectively break down their stored glycogen for energy, especially during exercise. This energy deficit leads to exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, weakness, and fatigue as the muscles quickly run out of available fuel. The high levels of CK (creatine kinase) and myoglobinuria (myoglobin in urine, causing dark urine) indicate muscle breakdown (rhabdomyolysis) that occurs when muscle cells are severely stressed due to the energy crisis. The high glycogen content on PAS staining in muscle biopsy is a direct consequence of the enzyme deficiency; glycogen cannot be broken down and thus accumulates within the muscle cells. Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • B) Muscle PFK-1 (Phosphofructokinase-1): A deficiency in muscle PFK-1 causes Tarui's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VII). While it also presents with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria due to impaired glycolysis, the enzyme involved is different, and the specific accumulation would be more proximal to the PFK-1 step rather than just glycogen.
  • • C) Hepatic phosphorylase: Deficiency of hepatic (liver) phosphorylase causes Hers' disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI). This primarily affects the liver's ability to release glucose into the bloodstream, leading to hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, not primarily muscle symptoms like myalgia and myoglobinuria.
  • • D) Acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase): Deficiency of acid maltase causes Pompe disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type II). This is a lysosomal storage disease, affecting various tissues, including muscle and heart, due to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. While it causes muscle weakness, its presentation can vary from infantile onset with severe cardiomyopathy to milder adult-onset forms, and the mechanism and primary location of glycogen accumulation differ from McArdle's disease.

questions.text: A patient on primaquine therapy present with hemolysis. The enzyme inhibited is present in the following pathway ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical scenario describes a patient on primaquine therapy who develops hemolysis. This is a classic presentation of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Primaquine is an oxidant drug that generates reactive oxygen species (ROS).
  • • Here's the connection to the HMP shunt:
  • • Red blood cells are constantly exposed to oxidative stress. They rely heavily on a protective mechanism involving reduced glutathione (GSH), a powerful antioxidant. Glutathione reductase is the enzyme responsible for regenerating GSH from its oxidized form (GSSG). This reaction crucially requires NADPH. The primary source of NADPH in red blood cells (which lack mitochondria and therefore cannot perform oxidative phosphorylation or the Krebs cycle) is the Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP). The rate-limiting enzyme of the HMP shunt is Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD). This enzyme catalyzes the first committed step in the oxidative phase of the HMP shunt, producing NADPH. In individuals with G6PD deficiency, there is an insufficient amount of functional G6PD enzyme. Consequently, they cannot produce enough NADPH. When exposed to oxidative stress (like from primaquine), their red blood cells are unable to regenerate sufficient GSH to neutralize the ROS. This leads to oxidative damage to hemoglobin (forming Heinz bodies) and the red blood cell membrane, ultimately causing hemolysis. Therefore, the enzyme inhibited (or deficient, in this case, G6PD) is a key enzyme in the HMP shunt, which is essential for protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • B) Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is the metabolic pathway that produces glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors. It primarily occurs in the liver and kidneys. It is not directly related to red blood cell metabolism or the mechanism of primaquine-induced hemolysis.
  • • C) Fatty acid synthesis: Fatty acid synthesis is the process of creating fatty acids from acetyl-CoA. This pathway primarily occurs in the cytoplasm of liver, adipose, and mammary gland cells. While NADPH is also required for fatty acid synthesis, this pathway is not directly relevant to the specific mechanism of primaquine-induced hemolysis in red blood cells.
  • • D) Glycolysis: Glycolysis is the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to pyruvate, generating a small amount of ATP. While glycolysis is active in red blood cells for energy production, it does not directly produce NADPH, which is critical for antioxidant defense against drugs like primaquine. Therefore, defects in glycolysis would not directly lead to hemolysis via the same oxidative stress mechanism as seen with primaquine.

questions.text: Change in basse sequence leading to generation of stop codon is called
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A nonsense mutation is a type of point mutation in a DNA sequence that results in a premature stop codon (also known as a "nonsense codon") being generated in the messenger RNA (mRNA) transcript. This stop codon signals the termination of protein synthesis before the full-length protein can be made. The resulting truncated protein is often non-functional or unstable, leading to a loss of protein function, which can have significant phenotypic consequences. The three common stop codons are UAA, UAG, and UGA.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • A) Silent mutation: A silent mutation is a type of point mutation that changes a single nucleotide in the DNA sequence, but this change does not alter the amino acid sequence of the protein. This is possible due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, where multiple codons can code for the same amino acid. Therefore, it does not lead to the generation of a stop codon.
  • • B) Missense mutation: A missense mutation is a type of point mutation where a single nucleotide change results in a codon that codes for a different amino acid. This leads to a change in the protein's amino acid sequence. While it can affect protein function, it does not involve the creation of a stop codon.

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Gamma-glutamyl carboxylase is an enzyme that catalyzes the vitamin K-dependent carboxylation of specific glutamic acid residues (Glu) into gamma-carboxyglutamic acid (Gla) residues. This post-translational modification is crucial for the biological activity of a group of proteins known as Vitamin K-dependent proteins.
  • • In the context of blood coagulation, the zymogens (inactive precursors) that require this carboxylation by gamma-glutamyl carboxylase are:
  • • Factor II (Prothrombin) Factor VII Factor IX Factor X These four factors are often referred to as the "prothrombin group" of clotting factors. The addition of the carboxyl groups to the glutamic acid residues allows these proteins to bind calcium ions (Ca2+) with high affinity. This calcium binding is essential for their proper conformation and for anchoring them to phospholipid surfaces (like those on activated platelets), which is critical for the assembly of functional enzyme complexes in the coagulation cascade.
  • • A deficiency in vitamin K (e.g., due to malabsorption, antibiotic use, or antagonism by drugs like warfarin) or a defect in the gamma-glutamyl carboxylase enzyme itself leads to the production of under-carboxylated and non-functional clotting factors, resulting in bleeding disorders.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • A) Factors 2, 8, 9, 10: Factor VIII (antihemophilic factor A) is a cofactor in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, but it is not a vitamin K-dependent protein and does not require gamma-glutamyl carboxylation. It is a large glycoprotein that circulates bound to von Willebrand factor.
  • • C) Factors 2, 7, 9, 11: Factor XI is part of the intrinsic pathway, but it is not a vitamin K-dependent protein and does not require gamma-glutamyl carboxylation.
  • • D) Factors 2, 8, 10, 11: This option includes both Factor VIII and Factor XI, neither of which are vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.

questions.text: A young boy presents to OPD with hypoglycemia and muscle cramps while playing. Then he becomes normal after resting for some time. These episodes are recurrent after activity. He has decreased serum lactate and glucose levels. Which of the following diseases is he most likely suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The constellation of symptoms in the young boy strongly points to McArdle's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type V, GSD V). Let's break down why:
  • • Hypoglycemia and muscle cramps while playing (activity intolerance): This is a hallmark of McArdle's. Muscles primarily use glycogen for immediate energy during exercise. If muscle glycogen cannot be broken down (due to enzyme deficiency), muscles quickly run out of fuel, leading to cramps, pain, and fatigue. While playing, the boy is relying on muscle glycogen, which he can't access. Becomes normal after resting for some time (Second Wind Phenomenon): This is a classic feature of McArdle's disease. After a short period of rest, the body shifts to using alternative fuels like free fatty acids and glucose from the bloodstream (delivered from the liver). This allows the individual to resume activity with less discomfort. Recurrent episodes after activity: Consistent with the reliance on muscle glycogen during exercise. Decreased serum lactate: This is a crucial diagnostic clue. During normal anaerobic glycolysis (when muscles break down glucose for energy during intense exercise), pyruvate is converted to lactate. In McArdle's disease, the block in glycogen breakdown (at the phosphorylase step) means that insufficient glucose can enter glycolysis, thus limiting pyruvate formation and subsequent lactate production. This is often demonstrated in an "ischemic forearm exercise test" where lactate fails to rise. Decreased glucose levels (though less prominent than lactate in diagnostic context): While muscle glycogen breakdown is the primary issue, severe exercise intolerance can sometimes lead to relative hypoglycemia as the body struggles to meet energy demands, especially if liver glycogen stores are also being depleted without efficient muscle energy utilization. Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • B) Hers' disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI): This disease involves a deficiency in hepatic (liver) phosphorylase. The primary symptoms are hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) and hypoglycemia due to the liver's inability to release glucose from its glycogen stores, especially during fasting. Muscle cramps and exercise intolerance are not the primary features, and lactate levels would not be decreased in this manner.
  • • C) Cori's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III): This disease involves a deficiency in the debranching enzyme (amylo-1,6-glucosidase). It affects both the liver and muscles. Patients can experience hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and muscle weakness, and exercise intolerance. However, unlike McArdle's, some glycogen breakdown can occur (up to the branch points), and lactate levels can rise, though perhaps not normally. The specific "decreased lactate" and "second wind" phenomenon are more characteristic of McArdle's.
  • • D) Andersen disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV): This disease involves a deficiency in the branching enzyme. This leads to the formation of abnormal, long, unbranched glycogen molecules, which are less soluble and can trigger an inflammatory response. It primarily affects the liver, leading to progressive cirrhosis, liver failure, and often cardiac involvement. Muscle symptoms are less prominent, and the presentation of hypoglycemia and exercise intolerance with decreased lactate is not typical.

questions.text: A family who consumes only polished rice will which of the following combinations of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Polished Rice and Thiamine Deficiency: Polished rice (white rice) is rice that has had its outer layers (bran and germ) removed during milling. These outer layers are rich in Thiamine (Vitamin B1). When a diet consists primarily of polished rice, it leads to a significant deficiency of thiamine, a condition known as Beriberi.
  • • Thiamine and Transketolase: Thiamine, in its active form as thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), is an essential coenzyme for several key enzymes in carbohydrate metabolism. One of the most important of these is transketolase, an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt (also known as the pentose phosphate pathway). Transketolase plays a crucial role in connecting the HMP shunt to glycolysis, and its activity is directly dependent on adequate thiamine levels.
  • • Diagnostic Test: The activity of erythrocyte (red blood cell) transketolase is a widely used and reliable biochemical test to assess thiamine nutritional status. In individuals with thiamine deficiency, the baseline activity of transketolase will be low. When exogenous TPP is added in vitro, the enzyme's activity will increase significantly if the deficiency is due to insufficient thiamine, providing a diagnostic "activation coefficient."
  • • Therefore, a family consuming only polished rice is highly likely to develop thiamine deficiency, and the enzymatic defect most directly linked to assessing this deficiency is in transketolase.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • A) Riboflavin-glutathione reductase: While riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can be assessed by measuring erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity (as glutathione reductase requires FAD, derived from riboflavin, as a cofactor), the primary vitamin lost during rice polishing is thiamine, not riboflavin.
  • • B) Riboflavin-transketolase: Transketolase is dependent on thiamine, not riboflavin. While riboflavin is an important vitamin, it's not the primary one lost by polishing rice, nor is it the cofactor for transketolase.
  • • C) Thiamine-Transaminase: While thiamine is the correct vitamin here, transaminases (like aspartate transaminase or alanine transaminase) primarily require pyridoxal phosphate (Vitamin B6) as a coenzyme, not thiamine. Therefore, measuring transaminase activity is used to assess Vitamin B6 status.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The symptoms described – confusion, ataxia (lack of muscle coordination), and painful eye movements (ophthalmoplegia or nystagmus, sometimes manifesting as painful eye movements) – in a chronic alcoholic patient are the classic triad of Wernicke encephalopathy. Wernicke encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder caused by a severe deficiency of Thiamine (Vitamin B1), which is one of the B vitamins.
  • • Chronic alcoholism is the most common cause of thiamine deficiency in developed countries for several reasons:
  • • Inadequate dietary intake: Alcoholics often have poor nutritional habits, consuming calories from alcohol instead of nutrient-rich foods. Decreased absorption: Alcohol interferes with the absorption of thiamine from the gastrointestinal tract. Impaired utilization and storage: Alcohol can impair the liver's ability to store thiamine and convert it into its active form (thiamine pyrophosphate). Increased metabolic demand: Alcohol metabolism itself may increase the demand for thiamine. Thiamine is crucial for carbohydrate metabolism, which is the brain's primary energy source. Its deficiency leads to impaired energy production in brain regions highly dependent on thiamine, causing the neurological symptoms. If left untreated, Wernicke encephalopathy can progress to Korsakoff syndrome, characterized by severe, irreversible memory loss and confabulation (making up stories to fill memory gaps). The combination is known as Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • B) Vitamin A deficiency: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, xerophthalmia (dry eyes), and impaired immune function. It does not cause confusion, ataxia, or painful eye movements in the way seen with thiamine deficiency.
  • • C) Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with bone health issues (rickets in children, osteomalacia in adults), muscle weakness, and potentially impaired immune function. It does not typically present with acute neurological symptoms like confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.
  • • D) Vitamin C deficiency: Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) causes symptoms like bleeding gums, easy bruising, poor wound healing, fatigue, and joint pain due to impaired collagen synthesis. It does not cause the specific neurological triad seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 4 year old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. The enzyme likely to be deficient is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation of a 4-year-old child with:
  • • Easy fatigability: Suggests an energy deficit. Increased hunger between meals, relieved after food: This is a classic sign of hypoglycemia (low blood sugar), as the body demands more glucose. Liver examination revealed no glycogen: This is the most crucial diagnostic clue. The liver is the primary organ for synthesizing and storing glycogen, which it then breaks down to maintain blood glucose levels during fasting or between meals. If there is no glycogen in the liver, it means the liver cannot synthesize it. The enzyme responsible for synthesizing glycogen is glycogen synthase. A deficiency in hepatic (liver) glycogen synthase is known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type 0 (GSD 0). In this condition, the liver cannot build up glycogen stores. Consequently, when the child is fasting or between meals, the liver cannot release glucose from glycogen stores, leading to severe and recurrent hypoglycemia, which manifests as increased hunger, fatigue, and potential neurological symptoms if prolonged.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • A) Glycogen phosphorylase: A deficiency in hepatic glycogen phosphorylase causes Hers' disease (GSD VI). In this condition, the liver can synthesize glycogen (so there would be glycogen present), but it cannot break it down efficiently. This leads to hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) and hypoglycemia, but the liver would show increased glycogen content, not an absence.
  • • C) Glucose-6-phosphatase: A deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase causes Von Gierke's disease (GSD Ia). This is a severe form of GSD characterized by profound hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. In this disease, glycogen is accumulated in the liver and kidneys because the final step of glucose release from glycogen and gluconeogenesis is blocked. The liver would have a large amount of glycogen, not none.
  • • D) Debranching enzyme: A deficiency in the debranching enzyme (amylo-1,6-glucosidase) causes Cori's disease (GSD III). This affects both the liver and muscles. In this condition, glycogen is synthesized, but it cannot be fully broken down due to the inability to debranch. This leads to the accumulation of abnormal, short-branched glycogen structures. The liver would have abnormal but present glycogen, and patients experience hypoglycemia and muscle weakness. Again, it would not be an absence of glycogen.

questions.text: A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis. Cardiomegaly was present. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The combination of symptoms in the child – pedal edema (swelling of the feet/ankles) and cardiomegaly (enlarged heart) – along with cheilosis (cracking at the corners of the mouth) strongly points to Wet Beriberi.
  • • Wet Beriberi is a severe form of Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency that primarily affects the cardiovascular system. Cardiomegaly, edema, and heart failure are hallmark symptoms of wet beriberi. Thiamine is crucial for energy metabolism in cardiac muscle. Its deficiency impairs the heart's ability to pump effectively, leading to fluid retention and enlargement of the heart. In severe cases, this can lead to high-output cardiac failure. Cheilosis (cracking at the corners of the mouth) is a general symptom of several B vitamin deficiencies, but when combined with the severe cardiovascular symptoms, it fits well within the spectrum of thiamine deficiency. Thiamine is essential for several metabolic pathways, particularly in carbohydrate metabolism (e.g., as a coenzyme for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase), which are critical for energy production in highly metabolic tissues like the heart.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Responses:
  • • A) Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Riboflavin deficiency (ariboflavinosis) can cause cheilosis, angular stomatitis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. While riboflavin deficiency can be associated with some cardiac abnormalities in severe, prolonged cases, the specific presentation of prominent pedal edema and cardiomegaly as primary signs of heart failure is far more characteristic of thiamine deficiency (wet beriberi) than riboflavin deficiency.
  • • C) Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency can lead to peripheral neuropathy, dermatitis, cheilosis, glossitis, and microcytic anemia. It is not typically associated with prominent cardiovascular symptoms like cardiomegaly and pedal edema.
  • • D) Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis (especially photosensitive), diarrhea, and dementia. While cheilosis can occur in pellagra, and some systemic issues can arise, the specific combination of severe cardiomegaly and pedal edema is not a primary or characteristic feature of niacin deficiency.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. What biochemical changes will be seen in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Increased urate and lactate levels
